channel.title: NYT > Africa
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gambians Celebrate Defeat of Longtime President
item.media:description: Adama Barrow, Gambia’s president-elect. His rise happened quickly late in the race.
item.description: After Yahya Jammeh, who led Gambia for 22 years, lost an election on Thursday, thousands of people across the country welcomed the end of his oppressive government,
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Gambia’s President, in Power 22 Years, Loses Election
item.media:description: Adama Barrow, the opposition candidate, campaigning in Talinding, Gambia, on Tuesday. He was declared the winner on Friday.
item.description: The electoral commission declared Adama Barrow the upset victor over Yahya Jammeh, one of Africa’s most eccentric leaders.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Gambians Choose Between Ruler of 22 Years and a United Opposition
item.media:description: Voters at a polling station in Banjul, the Gambian capital, on Thursday.
item.description: President Yahya Jammeh predicted a decisive win, but his challenger, Adama Barrow, said, “He is not going to be re-elected — his era is finished.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: One of World’s Most Wanted Hashish Smugglers Arrested in Morocco
item.media:description: Ben Ziane Berhili, one of the world’s most wanted hashish smugglers, was arrested in Casablanca.
item.description: The capture of Ben Ziane Berhili was the highest-profile arrest yet in an operation that has seized $3.2 billion worth of hashish since 2013.
item.dc:creator: LORENZO TONDO

item.title: Mont Péko Journal: Ousting Squatter Farmers to Save Forest, Ivory Coast Sets Off New Crisis
item.media:description: Workers filling sacks with cocoa beans at an agricultural cooperative in Guiglo, Ivory Coast.
item.description: Squatters using protected land to grow cocoa have helped strip the country of four-fifths of its woodlands. Now evicted, many of them are struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: SEAN LYNGAAS

item.title: Ousmane Sow, Sculptor of Larger-Than-Life Figures, Dies at 81
item.media:description: Ousmane Sow on the Pont des Arts in Paris in 1999 with his works that were exhibited there.
item.description: In his art, the Senegal-born Mr. Sow relied on his knowledge of the human anatomy from his years working as a physical therapist.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Gambia’s Leader Vowed to Rule for a Billion Years. A Vote Will Test That.
item.media:description: President Yahya Jammeh’s final rally in Banjul, Gambia, on Tuesday, ahead of the presidential election.
item.description: Enthusiasm for President Yahya Jammeh’s rival has put into question the outcome of the country’s election and prompted fears of instability and violence.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Tunisia Seeks Foreign Investment to Cement Democratic Gains
item.media:description: Prime Minister Youssef Chahed of Tunisia at Parliament in Tunis this month. Only three months into the job, he faces the urgent task of rescuing the economy.
item.description: The country where the Arab Spring began five years ago is trying to bolster its economy, especially in the less developed interior, as it combats terrorism.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Trilobites: Study Suggests 3.2 Million-Year-Old Lucy Spent a Lot of Time in Trees
item.media:description: The fossil specimen of Australopithecus afarensis known as Lucy.
item.media:credit: John Kappelman/The University of Texas at Austin
item.description: The bones of the famous fossil were pretty thick, suggesting she had a ratio of strength between her arms and legs more like a chimp than a human.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: A.N.C. Rejects Calls for Jacob Zuma to Quit South African Presidency
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa in Johannesburg this month.
item.description: Leaders of the African National Congress, after a debate among party members, reaffirmed their support for the unpopular leader.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa Faces Leadership Challenge
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa, shown during the opening of parliament last year in Cape Town, has been embroiled in one scandal after another since taking office in 2009.
item.description: The African National Congress’s national executive committee introduced, for the first time, a motion urging the embattled Mr. Zuma to step down.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Global Health: Summer Project Turns Into Leukemia Testing Breakthrough
item.media:description: Researchers with a sample card with dried blood that can be used to test for chronic myeloid leukemia.
item.description: What began as a student effort at a lab in Seattle produced a test for chronic myeloid leukemia that works with a few spots of dried blood on a paper card.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Al Jazeera Film Critical of Egyptian Army Strains Egypt-Qatar Ties Further
item.media:description: Sameh Shoukry, the foreign minister of Egypt.
item.description: The documentary, broadcast on a network owned by the Qatari government, accuses Egypt of abusing its recruits, and the country was quick to denounce it.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: A Forgotten Step in Saving African Wildlife: Protecting the Rangers
item.media:description: David Piroris, left, and Solomon Ngila of the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy’s antipoaching dog unit in Kenya, training Maxo.
item.description: Many park personnel, responsible for fending off poachers, go without basic necessities like boots, tents and health insurance. Some groups are trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Ugandan Troops Move Against Tribal King in Rebel Region
item.description: Security forces clashed with palace guards and removed the leader of the Bakonzo people, a vocal critic of President Yoweri Museveni.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Expands War With Al Qaeda to Include Shabab in Somalia
item.media:description: Bystanders surveyed damage from a car bomb in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Saturday. The blast killed at least 11 people and wounded 16 others.
item.description: The administration’s move to stretch a 2001 war authorization will strengthen Donald J. Trump’s authority to combat thousands of Somali militants, and has drawn objections from some experts.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE, ERIC SCHMITT and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: What in the World: Which Language Uses the Most Sounds? Click 5 Times for the Answer
item.media:description: Speakers of Khoisan languages, like the San people in Namibia, use click consonants, packing a lot of information into brief words.
item.description: Taa, spoken by a few thousand people in Botswana and Namibia, is believed to have the largest sound inventory of any language in the world.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Land Mine Casualties Jump 75% as Funding for Their Removal Declines
item.media:description: A de-mining operation in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, in February.
item.description: An annual report on the treaty banning land mines showed that casualties hit 6,461 last year, a sharp rise from 2014 and the highest level in a decade.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Global Health: Telling Mosquitoes Apart With a Cellphone
item.media:description: West Nile virus is spread by Culex mosquitoes.
item.description: Calling their project “Shazam for Mosquitoes,” Stanford students showed that common mobile phones could distinguish the hums of beating wings, which could prove useful in fighting diseases.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene

item.title: Silenced for Decades, ‘Victims of Despotism’ Air Torture Claims in Tunisia
item.media:description: Mothers of torture victims carried their sons’ portraits before the Truth and Dignity Commission hearings in Tunis on Thursday.
item.description: In long-awaited public hearings, victims and their families recounted abuses from nearly 60 years of dictatorship, including death and persecution.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Fuel Truck Explosion Kills at Least 73 in Mozambique
item.description: Villagers in a remote part of the African country had been trying to siphon fuel from the vehicle when it was struck by lightning.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Editorial: A Foolish Power Grab in Congo
item.media:description: President Joseph Kabila, center, of the Democratic Republic of Congo, at a special joint session of parliament on Tuesday.
item.description: President Joseph Kabila’s move to stay in office beyond his term could lead to renewed war in his troubled country.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Fixes: Up in the Sky, Help to Keep Africans From Starving
item.description: Satellite images help insurers predict when drought is likely to kill cattle, so they can aid herders whose own lives depend on their livestock.
item.dc:creator: TINA ROSENBERG

item.title: Africa Takes Its Turn on the Runway
item.media:description: Tatum Keshwar, a former Miss South Africa, walks in David Tlale’s show on the Nelson Mandela Bridge in Johannesburg in 2011.
item.description: For “African Catwalk,” the Swedish photographer Per-Anders Pettersson spent five years documenting the energy of Africa’s emerging fashion industry.
item.dc:creator: WHITNEY RICHARDSON

item.title: Lens Blog: Young Africans, Wrapped in Tradition
item.media:description: Soukeyna is studing marketing in France. She is wearing her great-grandmother’s outfit from Ivory Coast.
item.description: Joana Choumali, a photographer from Ivory Coast, is documenting modern African women wearing traditional clothing. She said these portraits allow her subjects to reconnect with their family history.
item.dc:creator: WHITNEY RICHARDSON

item.title: Can Television Be Fair to Muslims?
item.description: Writers and showrunners — including those for “24” and “Quantico” — talk about casting, cultural gaps and the networks’ desire for stories about terrorism.
item.dc:creator: MELENA RYZIK

item.title: Behind Tiger Woods’s Return, a (Ryder Cup) Team Effort
item.media:description: Tiger Woods, right, with Bubba Watson after the United States defeated Europe at this year’s Ryder Cup.
item.description: After Woods’s selfless work as an assistant captain, members of the winning United States squad showed their support for him in his comeback from a back injury.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Sports of The Times: At Liberty University, All Sins Are Forgiven on the Altar of Football
item.media:description: Ian McCaw, left, and Ken Starr, then Baylor’s president, with the women’s basketball team in February. Both left the school amid a sexual violence scandal that engulfed the football program.
item.description: Liberty, a Christian university that covets a higher athletic profile, looked the other way and found an athletic director who did the same.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POWELL

item.title: Feature: ‘We Are Orphans Here’
item.media:description: Palestinian children waiting inside the Shuafat Refugee Camp for buses to take them to school.
item.media:credit: Luca Locatelli/Institute, for The New York Times
item.description: Life and death in East Jerusalem’s Palestinian refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL KUSHNER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Feature: How to Hide $400 Million
item.description: When a wealthy businessman set out to divorce his wife, their fortune vanished. The quest to find it would reveal the depths of an offshore financial system bigger than the U.S. economy.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
